journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Simultaneous fault detection and control for switched systems under asynchronous switching

article-meta.aff: 1College of Information Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, China
2State Key Laboratory of Synthetical Automation for Precess Industries, Northeastern University, China

author-notes.corresp: Guang-Hong Yang, College of Information Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, Shenyang 110819, China. Email: yangguanghong@ise.neu.edu.cn

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on advanced control of aerospace vehicles

abstract.p: This paper is concerned with a fault-detection and control problem for discrete-time switched systems, which are modeled using different operating points for the flight envelope. The fault detector and controller designed simultaneously have asynchronous switching with the original switched system. For the fault-detection objectives, estimation errors between residual signals and faults are minimized by applying weighted matrices to restrict the frequency ranges of faults, and the weighted l2-gain performance is simultaneously considered for the control objectives. A two-step procedure is adopted to obtain solutions through satisfying a set of linear matrix inequalities. A simulation on the longitudinal motion of a highly maneuverable aircraft technology vehicle is given to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Over recent years, there has been strong interest and intensive research activities in the area of aerospace vehicles, such as manned/unmanned airplanes, hypersonic vehicles, satellites and missiles. Many papers have focused on flight control, such as fault-tolerant control,1–3 fault detection and diagnosis.4,5 In particular, the simultaneous fault-detection and control (SFDC) problem has received increasing interest due to lower overall complexity. Wang and Yang 6 directly considered a fault-sensitivity performance index in a given frequency range, and a generalized Kalman-Yakubovic-Popov (KYP) lemma was used to obtain sufficient conditions for the solution of the SFDC problem. A robust integrated controller/diagnosis aircraft application was proposed by Macros and Balas.7 Ding8 reviewed a controller and fault detector in feedback control loops.

Another issue encountered in flight control is that the design objectives and the aircraft dynamics may be different in each operating point for the flight envelope. A modern aircraft usually works with multi-operating points. In this case, the aircraft mode can be modeled as a switched system. Switched systems have hybrid features, consisting of a finite number of subsystems, and a logical rule specifying orchestrated switching between them.9–12 Switching control has been applied in a wide range of physical and engineering systems, such as aircraft multi-mode control,13 missile autopilot design14 and spacecraft formation control.15 To date, there are many methods to obtain stability criteria for switched systems, such as the common Lyapunov function method, the multiple Lyapunov function method,16 the average dwell time (ADT) method17–20 and switched Lyapunov function method,21–23 etc.

In these papers, a common assumption was that controllers, observers or filters and the original switched systems switched at the same time. It should be pointed out, however, as in Xie and Wu,24 in many practical switched systems, the switching signal is created by some unknown or non-deterministic function. Even if the switching signal can be detected, the change of the switching signal may not be detected instantaneously, but only after a time period. Thus, there exists asynchronous switching between controllers, observers or filters with the original switched systems. Moveover, since the approaches for the design of synchronous switching are not appropriate for the asynchronous case, a new technique should be considered to solve the asynchronous switched case.

In this paper, we present the SFDC problem to design a family of detectors and controllers that are suitable for different operating points of the flight envelope. The whole framework is based on discrete-time switched linear systems, and the detector/controller switched asynchronously with the original switched system is designed as a single unit, and generates two signals: a detection signal and a control signal, which are used to detect faults and guarantee control indices, respectively. In this paper, the result developed for weighted l2-gain for the asynchronous switching case is given, which extends the multiple Lyapunov-like functions during the matched period and the unmatch period, and the bounded real lemma (BRL) for the switched systems under asynchronous switching is obtained. This method is different from that of Zhang and Shi25 and Zhang et al.,26 which uses a single Lyaounov-like function during the matched period and the unmatched period for the running time of one subsystem, and less conservatism is achieved in this paper. Subsequently, conditions are obtained to guarantee that the estimation errors between the residual signals and the faults are minimized for the fault-detection objectives. Simultaneously, the conditions are achieved such that the closed-loop switched systems can be stabilized and acquire given performances for the control objectives. To the best of our knowledge, the problem of SFDC design for switched systems under asynchronous switching has not yet been investigated. A two-step procedure, as stated in Kanev et al.,27 is adopted to obtain the solutions through satisfying a set of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). A simulation on the longitudinal motion of highly maneuverable aircraft technology (HiMAT) vehicle switching between two operating points is given to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

The paper is organized as follows. The following section introduces the problem under consideration and presents the design objectives. Then, the SFDC is studied in detail, and the thresholds are given. Then, a simulation on HiMAT vehicles is given to demonstrate the proposed method. The conclusions of this paper are given in the last section.

Notation. For a matrix A, AT denotes its transpose. For a symmetric matrix, A>0 (A≥0) and A<0 (A≤0) denote positive-definiteness (positive semi-definite matrix)and negative-definiteness (negative semi-definite matrix), respectively. The Hermitian part of a square matrix M is denoted by He(M):=M+MT. The symbol * within a matrix represents the symmetric entries. 0 denotes the zero matrix with appropriate dimensions.

sec.title: System model
sec.p: Consider the following discrete-time switched linear systems

where x(k) is the state, y(k) is the measured output and z(k) is the performance output to the disturbance, d(k) is the disturbance input that is assumed to belong to l2[0∞) and f(k)∈l2[0∞) is the fault vector. The switching signal μj(k):Z+⌣{0,1} specifies that the j-th subsystem is activated when μj(k)=1 and ∑j=1Nμj(k)=1, k∈Z+. The matrices Aj, Bj1, Bj2, Bj3, Cj, Dj2, Dj3, Ej, Fj1 and Fj2 of each subsystem have appropriate dimensions, and switch with μj at a certain discrete time.
Design a detector/controller of the following form
where x^(k) is the detector/controller state vector and Akj,Bkj and Ckj are real matrices of appropriate dimensions to be determined.

For fault detection, it is not necessary to estimate the fault f(k) directly. Similar to Wang et al.22, we can formulate the fault as the weighted fault f^(k)=Wf(z)f(k) with a given stable weighted matrix. Assume the minimal realization of Wf(z) is
where x¯(k) is the state of the weighted fault f^(k) is the weighted fault, and Awj, Bwj, Cwj, Dwj are known constant matrices.

The switching moments 0=k0<k1<k2<⋯ are defined recursively as kl+1=inf{k>kl:μj(k)≠μj(kl)}, that is, kl denotes that there are l times switching. When the switching signal is not known in advance, the change of the switching signal can still be detected after a time period rather than instantaneously. Therefore, there exists a matched period and an unmatched period between the detector/controller and the original switched systems in actual operation. When the j-th subsystem is activated at the switching instant kl, the corresponding j-th detector/controller may activate at the instant kl+Δkl. Until the i-th subsystem is activated at the switching instant kl+1, the corresponding i-th detector/controller may activate at the instant kl+1+Δkl+1. For the time interval [kl+Δkl,kl+1), the j-th subsystem matches with the j-th detecton/controller, while there exists an unmatched period at time interval [kl,kl+Δkl). The evolution of the procedure can be similarly described by Figure 1.

caption.p: Evolution of the procedure under asynchronous switching.

sec.p: Denote the residual signal r(k)=y(k)−y^(k) and the fault estimate error ek=r(k)−f^(k). When t∈[k0,k1)∪[kl−1+Δkl−1,kl), by combining equations (1), (2) and (3), we have the following augmented model for the matched period
where x~(k)=[x(k)Tx^(k)Tx¯(k)T]T,w(k)=[d(k)T,f(k)T]T and
When t∈[kl,kl+Δkl), the augmented switched system for the unmatched period can be written as
where x~(k)=[x(k)Tx^(k)Tx¯(k)T]T,w(k)=[d(k)T,f(k)T]T and
Considering the matched period and the unmatched period, and combining equations (4) and (5), we obtain the augmented switched system as
To present the purpose of this paper more precisely, several definitions are introduced.
Definition 1. For any k0<ks<kv, denote Nμ(k)(ks,kv) as the switching number for the switched system Σ over (ks,kv). IfNμ(k)(ks,kv)≤N0+(kv−ks)/τaforτa>0, N0≥0, then τa is called the ADT.10

Definition 2. Given the scales γ>0, 0<α<1, 0<β, μ1≥1 and μ2≥1, the augmented system Σ under zero initial conditions is said to be exponentially stable with a weighted l2-gain γs, if the following condition holds
where γs=μ1θΔmax−1γ and θ=1+β1−α, for all non-zero d(k)∈l2[0,∞).

Remark 1. The weighted l2-gain performance means that the disturbance attenuation performance is different when the decay degree of the system is different. The scalar α denotes the decreasing rate of the multiple Lyapunov-like functions for each subsystem, while the scalar β indicates the increasing rate of the multiple Lyapunov-like functions during the running unmatched period. When Δmax=0,β=0,μ1=1,α⌣0, the weighted l2-gain performance for switched systems under asynchronous switching will approach the normal l2-gain performance for switched systems under synchronous switching.

sec.title: Problem formulation
sec.p: The frameworks of SFDC design: given the switched linear system (1) under the switching signal that satisfies the ADT, the detector/controller (2) are designed such that the augmented system Σ under asynchronous switching is exponentially stable, and the disturbance and the fault effects on the performance output z(k) and the fault estimate error e(k) are both minimized. The proposed fault-detection and isolation scheme is described in Figure 2.

caption.p: Evolution of the procedure with asynchronous switching.

sec.p: To detect the faults and control the system, our design objective of the detector/controller can be formulated as the following performance indices

Remark 2. Condition (7) is used for the detection objectives, when the fault estimate error e(k) is not disastrous by the disturbance d(k) and the fault f(k). Condition (8) is used for control objective. Condition (8) is used to increase the robustness against disturbance d(k) and ensure the fault f(k) is not disastrous. In the following section, inequality conditions for performance indices (7) and (8) will be provided.
Before ending this section, we introduce the following well-known lemma.

Lemma 1. (projection lemma). Given a symmetric matrix Θ∈Rn×n, and two matrices ℳ and ℋ of column dimension n, there exists a matrix ℱ that satisfies Θ+ℳTℱℋ+ℋTℱTℳ<0 if and only if the following two conditions hold: 𝒩ℳTΘ𝒩ℳ<0,𝒩ℋΘ𝒩ℋT<0, where 𝒩ℳ and 𝒩ℋ denote arbitrarily bases of null space of ℳ and ℋ, respectively.

sec.title: Fault-detection and control design
sec.p: Before the results are obtained, the SFDC problem design can be solved starting from the weighted l2 performance and the BRL for switched systems under asynchronous switching.

Remark 3. Lemma 2 can be regarded as an extension of lemma 2 in Zhang et al.28 and theorem 2 in Zhang and Shi.25 Let Δmax=0,β=0,μ1=1, (18) becomes

Using the same procedure as in the proof lemma 2, we can obtain lemma 2 in Zhang et al.,28 which corresponds to switched systems under synchronous switching are exponentially stable with the weighted l2-gain. Similarly, let μ1=1,Pij=Pi, and α⌣0, lemma 2 in this paper is reduced to theorem 2 in Zhang and Shi.25
By lemma 2, we can obtain a BRL for switched system Σ1 under asynchronous switching as in the following.
Lemma 3. Let 0<α<1, β>0, γ>0, μ1≥1 and μ2≥1 be constants. If there exist symmetric positive-definite matrices Pj,Pij,i,j∈ℒ such that the following inequalities hold
then, the switched system Σ1 under asynchronous switching is exponentially stable and guarantees the weighted l2 performance.

Thus, if the following inequalities hold
the switched system Σ1 under asynchronous switching is exponentially stable with a weighted l2 performance for any switching signal with the ADT satisfying (11) according to lemma 2. ■
Subsequently, inequality conditions for performances (7) and (8) are first given, and the desired detector/controller is constructed.

sec.title: Weighted l2 performance from e(k) to w(k)
sec.p: Theorem 1. Consider the switched system Σ, and let 0<α<1, 0<β, γ1>0, μ1>1, μ2>1 be constants. If there exist matrix variables Yaj, Gaj, Zaj, Xai, Hai, Mai, Nj, A^kj, B^kj, Ckj and symmetric positive-definite matrices
such that Θaj<0,Θaij<0 and
where
then the switched system Σ under asynchronous switching is exponentially stable for any switching signal with the ADT satisfying (11), and guarantees the weighted l2 performance
where γs1=μ1θΔmax−1γ1.
Proof. For the switched system Σ, replace A⌣j,B⌣j,C⌣j,D⌣j and A⌣ij,B⌣ij,C⌣ij,D⌣ij in (23) and (24) by the ones in Σ. By applying lemma 3, it is not difficult to obtain that (26) can be rewritten as

where Waj introduced by lemma 1 is the matrix variable of appropriate dimensions. Partition Waj as

and paj1,paj2 are set to be fixed parameters. Define A^kj=NjTAkj, B^kj=NjTBkj. Using the Schur complement, (34) becomes Θaj<0. In a similar way, we can obtain the condition Θaij<0 with the variable Waij as the structure as Waj. Hence, if the conditions Θaj<0, Θaij<0 and (30), hold, the switched system Σ for any non-zero w(k)∈l2[0,∞) under asynchronous switching is exponentially stable and has a weighted l2-gain γs1=μ1θΔmax−1γ1, which completes the proof.

sec.p: Theorem 2. Consider the switched system Σ, and let 0<α<1, 0<β, γ2>0, μ1>1, μ2>1 be constants. If there exist matrix variables Ybj,Gbj, Zbj, Xbi, Hbi, Mbi, Nj, A^kj, B^kj, Ckj and symmetric positive-definite matrices
such that Θbj<0,Θbij<0 and
where
then the switched system Σ under asynchronous switching is exponentially stable for any switching signal with the ADT satisfying (11), and guarantees the weighted l2 performance
where γs2=μ1θΔmax−1γ2.
Proof. Following the same lines as that for theorem 1, the proof of theorem 2 is immediate. ■

Remark 4. Scalar pqj1~pqj4,q∈{a,b},j∈ℒ are used to reduce conservatism for the same variable Nj in matrix variables Wqj and Wqij, q∈{a,b}. In particular, we can straightforwardly choose pqj1~pqj4,q∈{a,b},j∈ℒ as the same scalar.

sec.title: Algorithm
sec.p: In the previous sections, theorems 1 and 2 formulated the inequality conditions for the performances (7) and (8), respectively. It is noted that conditions Θqj<0,Θqij<0,q∈{a,b},i,j∈ℒ are all non-convex owing the product terms YqjTBj1Ckj,GqjTBj1Ckj,XqiTBi1Ckj,HqiTBi1Ckj,q∈{a,b}. To solve this problem, a two-step procedure is presented, which follows from the idea proposed by Kanev et al.27 This can be summarized as follows.

list-item.p: Step 1: design a robust state feedback gain matrix Ckj such that the performance indices (8) are satisfied for the closed-loop system with state feedback control u(k)=Ckjx(k). This problem is convex.

Step 2: put the state feedback gain matrix Ckj into the switched system Σ, and search for a solution of satisfy conditions in theorems 1 and 2 in terms of the unknown controller matrices A^kj and B^kj.

sec.title: State feedback design
sec.p: The state feedback case for switch system (1) is equivalent to consider the constant state feedback controller u(k)=Ckjx(k),j∈ℒ; the closed-loop switched system under asynchronous switching is described as
where w=[d(k)Tf(k)T]T,Bj=[Bj2,Bj3],Fj=[Fj20],Bij=[Bi2Bi3],Fij=[Fi20] and the following theorem can be used for the state feedback design.

The detector/controller parameter Ckj can be obtained by solving the following optimization problem

sec.title: Output feedback design
sec.p: After the detector/controller parameter Ckj is designed in step 1, substituting Ckj into the conditions Θqj<0,Θqij<0,q∈{a,b}, these LMIs become convex. The detector/controller parameters Akj and Bkj can be obtained by solving the following problem, given γ2

sec.title: Threshold computation
sec.p: After the gain matrices of the detectors/controllers Akj,Bkj,Ckj are designed, a residual evaluation function is established to evaluate the residual. One of the widely adopted residual evaluation functions Jr(k)(k) can be chosen as
where L is the length of the evaluation window. The residual evaluation function Jr(k)(k) denotes the average value from r(k−L) to r(k). We propose to use the following threshold
Consequently, the occurrence of faults can be detected by the following logic rule

sec.title: Example
sec.p: In this section, the HiMAT vehicle given in Hou et al.29 is shown to illustrate the effectiveness of our design method. For statement convenience, we select two operating points within the flight envelope, as depicted in Table 1, and construct a switched system using longitudinal short period linear models.

caption.p: Two operation points of the HiMAT vehicle.

sec.p: Assume that the two linear models can describe dynamic behavior of the HiMAT vehicle in the neighborhood of the two operation points. Using the zero-order hold equivalent method, with a sample time T=0.1 s, we obtain the discrete-time switched system consisting of two subsystems. The states is x=[δ,ξ], where δ and ξ denote the angle of attack and the pitch rate, respectively. The parameters are

The detector/controller (2) is designed to stabilize (1) and detect the fault f(k). Assume the maximum delay of asynchronous switching Δmax=2, and choose α=0.02,β=0.02,μ1=1,μ2=1.02. The parameters of the detector/controller are obtained as follows.
First, from step 1, we get the detector/controller parameter Ckj,j∈ℒ as
and the performance index γs2=0.0172, respectively.

For step 2, given γs2=1.0202, pajl=3, pbjl=0.2, j∈ℒ,l=1,2,3,4. The minimal realization of the weighted matrix of the fault is supposed to be Awj=0.5,Bwj=0.25,Cwj=1,Dwj=0.5,j∈ℒ. By solving the convex optimization problem (42), we obtain the optimal weighted l2-gain γs1=μ1θΔmax−1γ1=3.1938. Furthermore, by (2), the detector/controller with gain matrices are shown as

The minimal ADT, τa*=5 steps, is given by (11). The switching signal in this paper is generated by choosing an ADT of τa=6 steps, and shown in Figure 3. To illustrate the simulation results of the fault detection objective, the disturbances for each subsystem are d1(k)=d2(k)=0.8cos(0.53k). Consider the case (1) that the fault for the first subsystem with the unit amplitude occurs from 5 s to 10 s, that is 50 steps to 100 steps. The generated residual r(k) and the evolution of the residual evaluation function Jr(k) are shown in Figure 4. The simulation results show that Jr1>Jthr1 for k=50 steps, which means that the fault f1(k) for the first subsystem can be detected when the fault of the first subsystem occurs at k=50 steps. Hence, the fault for the first subsystem can be detected. Consider the case (2) that the fault for the second subsystem with unit amplitude also occurs from 50 steps to 100 steps. The generated residual r(k) and the evolution of the residual evaluation function Jr(k) are shown in Figure 5.

caption.p: Switching signal with the ADT τa≥6.
(a) Residual signal of the filers. (b) The residual evaluation function Jr(k) when the fault for the first subsystem occurs from 50 steps to 100 steps with a sample time Ts=0.1 s.
(a) Residual signal of the filers. (b) The residual evaluation function Jr(k) when the fault for the second subsystem occurs from 50 steps to 100 steps with a sample time Ts=0.1 s.

sec.p: To illustrate the simulation results of the control objectives, the disturbances for each subsystem are assumed to be d1(k)=d2(k)=0.8cos(0.53k). And the fault for each subsystem with unit amplitude occurs from 50 steps to 100 steps, respectively, the performance output z(k) of the closed-loop system is shown in Figure 6. From this figure, it can be concluded that the effects of disturbances d(k) and the fault f(k) on the performance output z(k) is not disastrous, and the detector/controller has stabilized the closed-loop system.

caption.p: Performance output z(k) for (a) the first subsystem and (b) the second subsystem occurs from 50 steps to 100 steps with a sample time Ts=0.1 s

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, the SFDC problem has been presented for flight control design. The fault detector and controller designed as a single unit asynchronous switches with the original switched flight systems. Firstly, the developed weighted l2 performance and the BRL have been obtained for switched systems under asynchronous switching. Subsequently, sufficient conditions are established not only for the fault-detection objectives, but also for the control objectives. A two-step procedure is adopted to obtain the solutions through satisfying a set of LMIs. The proposed methods are applied to the longitudinal motion of a HiMAT vehicle switching between two operating points, and promising simulation results are shown.

ack.p: This work was supported in part by the Funds for Creative Research Groups of China [grant no. 60821063], National 973 Program of China [grant no. 2009CB320604], the Funds of National Science of China [grant nos 60974043, 60904010, 61104015], and the 111 Project [B08015], the Funds of Doctoral Program of Ministry of Education, China [grant no. 20100042110027], China Postdoctoral Science Foundation [grant nos 2009045127 and 201003624] and a Foundation for the Author of National Excellent Doctoral Dissertation of PR China [no. 201157].
